{{more citations needed|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox Film Festival | name = Prague Independent Film Festival | image = Lazar Ristovski at the Prague Independent Film Festival (2).jpg | caption = | location = [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]] | awards = | founded = | number = | director = | website = {{url|http://prague-film-festival.com/}} }} '''Prague Independent Film Festival (PIFF)''' is an international film festival held annually in August in [[Prague]], the capital of [[Czech Republic]]. The festival focuses on independent cinema.
== History == ===2016=== Prague Independent Film Festival was held for the first time on 15–18 August 2016 in the cinemas Kino Evald, [[:cs:Kino Atlas|Kino Atlas]] and Kino Lucerna. The festival program consisted of 33 films. Opening film of the festival was ''Rocco has Your Name by'' [[:it: Angelo Orlando|Angelo Orlando]]. Angelo Orlando won the Best Screenplay award and the leading actor [[:it: Michele Venitucci|Michele Venitucci]] won the Best Actor award.
Grand Prix of the festival – The Golden Eagle – was awarded to the Bulgarian drama film ''[[Sinking of Sozopol]]'' by [[:bg: Костадин Бонев|Kostadin Bonev]].<ref>{{cite web|title="Филмът "Потъването на Созопол" се прибира с три награди от фестивал в Прага (Bulgarian)|url=http://btvnovinite.bg/video/videos/news/nov-uspeh-za-balgarskoto-kino.html|publisher=bTV Новините|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title="Потъването на Созопол" триумфира в Прага (Bulgarian)|url=http://www.standartnews.com/kultura-kino_tv/potavaneto_na_sozopol_triumfira_v_praga-341979.html|publisher=standartnews.com|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title="Потъването на Созопол" с три награди в Прага (Bulgarian)|url=http://flashnews.bg/potavaneto-na-sozopol-s-tri-nagradi-v-praga/|publisher=FlashNews (Bulgarian)|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title="The sinking of Sozopol claims three awards at Prague Independent Film Festival, 2016|url=http://bnr.bg/en/post/100728647/the-sinking-of-sozopol-claims-three-awards-at-prague-independent-film-festival-2016|publisher=BNR Radio Bulgaria|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref>
[[Shamim Sarif]] received the Best Feature Film award for her espionage drama ''[[Despite the Falling Snow (film)|Despite the Falling Snow]]'' based on the best selling eponymous novel written by herself.<ref>{{cite web|title=A trio of awards for Despite The Falling Snow|url=http://www.enlightenment-productions.com/blog/a-trio-of-awards-for-despite-the-falling-snow/|accessdate=13 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Thrilled to say #DespiteTheFallingSnow just won Best Feature Film at the Prague Independent Film Festival – @shamimsarif Tweet|url=https://twitter.com/shamimsarif/status/766954291856826368|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref> [[Rebecca Ferguson]] was awarded Best Actress and [[Anthony Head]] received the Best Supporting Actor award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://anthonyhead.org/updates-updates-updates/|publisher=Anthony Head – The Official Website|title=Updates, updates & updates!|accessdate=24 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Anthony Stewart Head on Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/AnthonySHead/status/767661097931374592|website=Twitter|accessdate=2 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=PIFF 2016 Winners {{!}} PIFF 2017|url=http://www.prague-film-festival.com/winners-2016.html|website=www.prague-film-festival.com|accessdate=2 December 2016}}</ref>
Best Animated Film was awarded to ''[[The Snow Queen 2: The Snow King|The Snow Queen 2]]'' from the Russian animation company [[Wizart Animation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Воронежский мультик "Снежная королева 2" оценили на кинофестивале в Чехии (Russian)|url=http://www.chr.aif.ru/voronezh/events/voronezhskiy_multik_snezhnaya_koroleva_2_ocenili_na_kinofestivale_v_chehii|publisher=Argumenty i Fakty|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Мультик воронежских аниматоров "Снежная королева 2" взял приз на фестивале в Праге (Russian)|url=http://www.vrn.kp.ru/online/news/2488910/|publisher=Komsomolskaya Pravda|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Воронежская "Снежная Королева-2" победила на кинофестивале в Праге (Russian)|url=https://news.mail.ru/society/26870928/|publisher=news.mail.ru|accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title="Снежная Королева-2: Перезаморозка" получила приз кинофестиваля в Праге (Russian)|url=http://www.kinobusiness.com/news/snezhnaya-koroleva-2-perezamorozka-poluchila-priz-kinofestivalya-v-prage-/|publisher=kinobusiness.com|accessdate=24 August 2016}}</ref> The film was written and directed by Aleksey Tsitsilin and produced by [[Timur Bekmambetov]].
Best Short Film award was given to the short film ''Cora'' made by Kevin Maxwell, a student of [[Santa Monica College]] who was supervised by [[Salvador Carrasco]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Santa Monica College Film Wins Prague Festival Award|url=http://www.surfsantamonica.com/ssm_site/the_lookout/news/News-2016/August-2016/08_24_2016_Santa_Monica_College_Film_Wins_Prague_Festival_Award.html|publisher=Santa Monica Lookout|accessdate=25 August 2016}}</ref>
===2017=== Opening film of the festival was ''[[Collector (2016 film)|Collector]]'' by Alexei Krasovsky. Alexei Krasovsky won the Best Director, Gustav Meyrink Prize and [[Konstantin Khabensky]] won the Best Actor award.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cinemaplex.ru/2017/08/10/novosti-festivalej-10-08-17.html|publisher=Cinemaplex|title=НОВОСТИ ФЕСТИВАЛЕЙ: "ПОСЛАНИЕ К ЧЕЛОВЕКУ", ПРИЗЫ ДЛЯ "КОЛЛЕКТОРА" В ПРАГЕ, ARTDOCFEST / RIGA IFF, KONIK FILM FESTIVAL, "РУДНИК"}}</ref><ref name="praguetv">{{Cite web|url=https://prague.tv/en/s72/c8-Cinema/n10429-Train-Driver-s-Diary-wins-at-Prague-Independent-Film-Festival|publisher=Prague TV|title=Train Driver's Diary wins at Prague Independent Film Festival}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kinobusiness.com/news/kollektor-otmechen-prizami-kinofestivalya-v-prage/|publisher=Kinobusiness|title="Коллектор" отмечен призами кинофестиваля в Праге}}</ref>
The film [[Maya Dardel]], written and directed by [[Magdalena Zyzak]] and [[Zachary Cotler]] won the Best Screenplay award and [[Lena Olin]] received the Best Actress award.<ref name="praguetv" /><ref name="piff-2017">{{Cite web|url=http://www.prague-film-festival.com/winners-2017.html|publisher=PIFF|title=PIFF 2017 Winners}}</ref>
[[Train Driver's Diary]] directed by [[:sr: Милош Радовић|Milos Radovic]] received the Grand Prix, Best Feature Film and [[Lazar Ristovski]] received the Best Actor prize.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rtv.rs/sr_lat/zivot/kultura/dnevniku-masinovodje-zlatna-zvezda-praga_845990.html|publisher=RTV|title=''Dnevniku mašinovođe'' "Zlatna zvezda" Praga}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraf.rs/vesti/kultura/2885147-pobeda-srpskog-filma-u-pragu-nagrada-i-lazi-ristovskom-video|title=Pobeda srpskog filma u Pragu: Nagrada i Lazi Ristovskom (VIDEO)|publisher=Telegraf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tanjug.rs/full-view_en.aspx?izb=349167|publisher=Tanjug|title=Train Driver's Diary wins awards at Prague festival}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> Konstantin Khabensky — 2018 (2).jpg|Actor and director [[Konstantin Khabensky]] receiving his honorary award from the festival director Lazar Ristovski at the Prague Independent Film Festival.jpg|Actor and producer [[Lazar Ristovski]] at the presentation of Train Driver's Diary Lazar Ristovski at the Prague Independent Film Festival (2).jpg|Lazar Ristovski presenting the film Train Driver's Diary Magdalena Zyzak and Zachary Cotler at the Prague Independent Film Festival.jpg|Directors Magdalena Zyzak and [[T. Zachary Cotler|Zachary Cotler]] presenting the film Maya Dardel Angelo Orlando and Saro Cosentino at the Prague Independent Film Festival.jpg | Director [[:it:Angelo Orlando|Angelo Orlando]] and musician [[:it:Saro Cosentino|Saro Cosentino]] presenting the film Rocco Has Your Name Angelo Orlando at the Prague Independent Film Festival.jpg | Angelo Orlando presenting the film Rocco Has Your Name Sinking of Sozopol Screening at the Prague Independent Film Festival.jpg | [[Sinking of Sozopol]] screening Kostadin Bonev at the Prague Independent Film Festival.jpg | [[:bg: Костадин Бонев|Kostadin Bonev]] with the Grand Prix </gallery>

Zachary Cotler|Zachary Cotler]] and Magdalena Zyzak – ''[[Maya Dardel]]'' Best Cinematography * Rana Kamran – ''[[Mah e Mir]]'' Best Actor * [[Lazar Ristovski]] – ''Train Driver's Diary'' * [[Konstantin Khabensky]] – ''Collector'' Best Actress * [[Lena Olin]] – ''Maya Dardel'' Best Short Film * ''The Light Thief'' – Eva Daoud Best Experimental Film * ''Time – Retrograde'' — Directed by David Ellis Best Art Direction * ''Ghosts on the Road to Camalt'' – Directed by Jason Tovey Best Music Video * ''God Came 'Round'' – Directed by [[Derek Frey]] Best Student Film * ''Muñecas'' – Directed by Ozzy Ozuna Gustav Meyrink Prize (Jury Prize) * ''Collector'' – Directed by Alexei Krasovsky

The '''RTMC Astronomy Expo''' is one of the major gatherings of [[amateur astronomy|amateur astronomers]] in the [[United States]].
== History ==
Founded by Clifford W. Holmes and the Riverside Astronomical Society, the RTMC Astronomy Expo began in 1969 as the Riverside Telescope Makers Conference at [[Riverside City College]] in [[Riverside, California|Riverside]], [[California]]. It consisted of a series of lectures about [[astronomy]] and [[telescope]] making with a competition for quality and innovative telescopes. In 1973 it was moved to a dark-sky site near [[Idyllwild, California|Idyllwild]] and in 1975 it was moved to its current home near [[Big Bear City, California|Big Bear City]]. It is held on the three-day [[Memorial Day]] weekend. In 2010, it was held in May on the weekend that corresponded with new moon to allow amateur astronomers the best viewing conditions. Due to low attendance the date was moved back to the Memorial Day weekend in 2011<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rtmcastronomyexpo.org/general.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-06-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130520204336/http://www.rtmcastronomyexpo.org/general.html |archivedate=2013-05-20 |df= }} RTMC Dates</ref>
The organization annually presents the [[Clifford W. Holmes Award]] for "Major Contribution to Popularizing Astronomy, the Warren Estes Memorial Award for "Best Use of Simple Materials and Technique" in making telescopes, and the [[Clyde Tombaugh]] Award "Creative Innovation in Telescope Design".
To better reflect the evolution of amateur astronomy, the Riverside Telescope Makers Conference was renamed the RTMC Astronomy Expo in 2003. Each year the scope of activities continues to grow and evolve and has lectures, workshops, extensive beginners activities, a swap meet, astronomy clubs and other organizations, and vendors demonstrating and selling astronomical products. The Expo continues to promote family activities with swimming, canoeing, horseback riding, archery, wall climbing. Extensive hiking and mountain biking trails are also available.
== Nightfall ==
The RTMC also produces an early autumn star party called Nightfall in [[Borrego Springs, CA]]. Nightfall is held on the weekend in October that corresponds with the new moon.
== Pacific Astronomy and Telescope Show (PATS) ==
In 2007, the Riverside Telescope Makers Conference, Inc. announced a fall event to be held in Pasadena named the Pacific Astronomy and Telescope Show (PATS). This annual event was held annually 2008 thru 2012 at the Pasadena Convention Center and focused displays by commercial vendors, astronomy clubs and other organizations as well as talks and workshops. The first PATS was held September 13–14, 2008. The 2013 event was cancelled. PATS was designed to complement the ongoing RTMC Astronomy Expo which continues to be held in Big Bear in May of each year.
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.rtmcastronomyexpo.org/ RTMC Homepage] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061024094259/http://rtmcastronomyexpo.org/archives/Holmes.htm The Clifford W. Holmes Award Web Page] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061026082539/http://rtmcastronomyexpo.org/archives/Estes.htm The Warren Estes Memorial Award Web Page] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061024034732/http://rtmcastronomyexpo.org/archives/Tombaugh.htm The Clyde Tombaugh Award Web Page]

{{advert|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = Red Frog Events | logo = [[File:RedFrogEvents Logo vert.jpg|frameless|alt=Red Frog Events.]] | type = [[Limited liability company|LLC]] | foundation = [[Chicago, IL]] ({{Start date|2007}}) | founder = Joe Reynolds
Ryan Kunkel | location = Chicago, IL, {{nowrap|United States}} | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Joe Reynolds
Ryan Kunkel | industry = Event Planning | num_employees = | homepage = {{URL|www.redfrogevents.com}} }}{{Refimprove|date=October 2018}} '''Red Frog Events, LLC''' is a privately owned (one member LLC with Joe Reynolds as the sole member) event production company founded in 2007 and based in [[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]]. The company's current events and services include [[Warrior Dash]], [[Firefly Music Festival]], [[ShamrockFest]], American Beer Classic, EventSprout, and Red Frog Food and Beverage. The company is known for its events and services in the experiential entertainment industry and its company culture. Joe Reynolds and Ryan Kunkel are the Co-CEO’s. ==History== Mirroring the television show ''[[The Amazing Race]]'', Joe Reynolds organized and launched [[Great Urban Race]], LLC and hosted the first race on September 15, 2007 in Chicago.{{cite web|title=Entrepreneurs Unpluggd|url=http://www.entrepreneursunpluggd.com/blog/red-frog-events|work=Interview with Red Frog Events|accessdate=18 November 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111027172021/http://www.entrepreneursunpluggd.com/blog/red-frog-events|archivedate=27 October 2011|df=}} In December 2008, Reynolds brought on four Event Coordinator interns ("Tadpoles") and moved the business into an office in Chicago's [[Lincoln Park, Chicago|Lincoln Park]] neighborhood to help keep up with the planning and organizing of Great Urban Race. In 2009, Ryan Kunkel joined Reynolds to expand Great Urban Race and develop new events. In the summer of 2009 the company was renamed Red Frog Events, LLC, and the first [[Warrior Dash]], was held in [[Joliet, Illinois|Joliet, IL]].{{cite news|title=Chicago Tribune|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-06-19/business/ct-biz-0619-confidential-races-20110619_1_staycation-ambition-craze|work=Joe Reynolds, Ryan Kunkel: Lead Warriors|accessdate=1 December 2011|date=19 June 2011}} In 2010, Red Frog Events moved from their Lincoln Park office to their current location at 320 West Ohio Street.{{cite web|title=Illinois State Business Magazine|url=http://blogs.ilstu.edu/business-magazine/2011/09/red-frog-events/|work=Red Frog Events|accessdate=1 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120528073933/http://blogs.ilstu.edu/business-magazine/2011/09/red-frog-events/|archivedate=28 May 2012|df=}} On November 13, 2010, the first [[Beach Palooza]] (later rebranded as Beach Dash to maintain consistency with their Warrior Dash race series) was held at Daytona Beach, FL.{{cite web|title=Timetoast timelines|url=http://www.timetoast.com/timelines/a-history-of-the-red-frog-family|work=A history of the Red Frog Family! timeline|accessdate=1 December 2011}} In 2011, Red Frog Bar Crawls were launched. The first event, a Halloween costume bar crawl called Nightmare on Clark Street, occurred on October 15, 2011 in Chicago. Snow Day in Washington D.C. was the next in the series on December 17. Two more bar crawls were introduced in 2012: Bright 'N' Tight in [[San Diego|San Diego, California]], and Derby Days in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]]. In 2012 the [[Firefly Music Festival]] was launched in [[Dover, Delaware]], and Farm to Fork, a 'farm style dinner,' took place on September 22 at McDonald Farm in [[Naperville, Illinois|Naperville, IL.]] In 2013 Red Frog launched three new running events: Iron Warrior Dash, Urban Warrior Dash, and Illuminite Run. They also launched the American Beer Classic beer festival and The Candy Cane Express. In 2014, Red Frog launched the Bacon Chase in Atlanta, GA on March 22, 2014. They also bought DC-based [[ShamrockFest]] from GoCity Events and began offering its ticketing platform, EventSprout, to third party event organizers. In 2015, Red Frog Events launched Big Barrel Country Music Festival and Red Frog Food and Beverage. On July 21, 2015, Red Frog laid off 29 of its roughly 105 employees.{{cite news|title= Red Frog Events lays off nearly a third of Chicago staff |url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20150721/NEWS07/150729960/red-frog-events-lays-off-nearly-one-third-of-chicago-staff|accessdate=24 July 2015|date=21 July 2015}} ==Events == === Runs === *[[Warrior Dash]] - a [[5K run|5k]] mud race with 12 obstacles. Since the inaugural race in 2009, more than 2.5 million people have competed in Warrior Dash.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/2015/11/02/obstacle-races-going-mainstream-more-popular-than-marathons/73743474/|title=Obstacle races going mainstream, more popular than marathons|last1=Perez|first1=A.J.|date=November 2, 2015|website=USA Today|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=November 2, 2015}} *[[Great Urban Race]] - an urban [[scavenger hunt]] that is held in cities across the United States. In a typical race, teams solve twelve clues and complete a variety of tasks while exploring the city. In 2011, there were 37 U.S. qualifying races and a qualifying race in Australia and Canada. The championship race was held on November 12, 2011 in New Orleans, LA. There were a total of 21 races across the country in 2012, with the championship race being held in [[Las Vegas|Las Vegas, NV]] on November 10. * The [[Beach Dash]] (formerly Beach Palooza) - a 5K race with 12 obstacles along a beach. Red Frog Events has hosted 11 Beach Dash runs across the nation. Because of low registration numbers in the US, Red Frog sold the event name and concept to an Australian events company in 2012. *Iron Warrior Dash - a longer (12+ miles) version of the Warrior Dash race series, * Urban Warrior Dash is an urban version of their Warrior Dash race series that takes place downtown in major metropolitan areas. * Illuminite Run is a night time run featuring lights and [[Electronic dance music|EDM music]]. *The Bacon Chase is a 5k and .05k un-timed run that features bacon at the water checkpoints at the finish line. === Festivals === * Firefly Music Festival is a music festival in Dover, DE. The festival lasts four days and features musical performances, dining, and entertainment at the [[Dover International Speedway]], which is transformed into a festival area featuring seven stages. The 2012 lineup featured [[The Killers]], [[Jack White]], [[The Black Keys]], [[John Legend]], [[The Flaming Lips]], [[OK Go|Ok Go]], [[Young the Giant|Young the Giant,]] and [[Cake (band)|Cake]]. Since 2012, Firefly has had headliners [[Paul McCartney]], [[Foo Fighters]], [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers]], [[Kings of Leon]], and [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]].{{cite web|last1=Peters|first1=Mitchell|title=Firefly Festival Director: 'We Want It to Be Talked About 50 Years From Now'|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/music-festivals/6598156/firefly-2015-festival-preview-interview|website=Billboard|publisher=Billboard|accessdate=2015-06-15}} * Big Barrel Country Music Festival{{cite web|last1=DeLuca|first1=Dan|title=Review: Big Barrel country fest, with Blake Shelton, Sturgill Simpson and more|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/blogs/inthemix/Review-Big-Barrel-country-festival-in-Delaware-with-Blake-Shelton-Sturgill-Simpson-and-more-.html|website=Philly.com|publisher=The Inquirer|accessdate=28 June 2015}} took place annually over three days in Dover, DE. The first and only year of the event was 2015. Red Frog Events and [[Goldenvoice]] partnered to produce and promote the country festival. 2015 headliners were [[Blake Shelton]], [[Miranda Lambert]], and [[Carrie Underwood]]. * American Beer Classic{{cite web|last1=Bernot|first1=Kate|title=American Beer Classic plans first festival for Soldier Field|url=http://articles.redeyechicago.com/2013-03-06/entertainment/37507674_1_chicago-craft-beer-week-first-festival-new-festival|website=RedEye|publisher=RedEye|accessdate=6 March 2013}} is a beer festival that takes place on Chicago’s [[Soldier Field]]. The festival began in 2013 and features hundreds of beers. In late 2015, American Beer Classic was rebranded to Chicago Beer Classic with the heightened focus on Chicago breweries. * ShamrockFest{{cite web|last1=Clabaugh|first1=Jeff|title=D.C.’s ShamrockFest sold to Chicago events producer|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/news/2014/12/03/d-c-s-shamrockfest-sold-to-chicago-events-producer.html|website=Washington Business Journal|accessdate=3 December 2014}} is a large [[Saint Patrick's Day in the United States|St. Patrick’s Day]] festival that takes place in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington D.C]]. The festival features live music, games, Irish food and an Irish market. === Bar crawls === * Nightmare on Clark Street, Chicago, IL * Snow Day, Washington D.C. * Bright 'N' Tight, San Diego, CA * Derby Days in Charlotte, NC === Other === * The Farm to Fork is a farm dinner in Naperville, IL. The inaugural Farm to Fork featured chef and Chicago native, Valerie Bolon. Farm to Fork took place on September 22 at Naperville's McDonald Farm which is also home to [[The Conservation Foundation (Illinois)|The Conservation Foundation]] as well as the [[Green Earth Institute]]. * Candy Cane Express is a holiday themed train ride through various parts of the Chicago area, featuring milk and cookies. == Platforms and services == * EventSprout{{cite web|last1=Sweeney|first1=Brigid|title=Chicago event firm Red Frog buys D.C.'s ShamrockFest|url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20141205/NEWS07/141209866/chicago-event-firm-red-frog-buys-d-c-s-shamrockfest|website=Crain's Chicago Business|accessdate=5 December 2014}} is an online registration platform. Red Frog began developing the system in 2009 and now offers it to third party events. * Red Frog Food and Beverage - food and beverage operation service formed when Red Frog acquired long time partner DJ’s National Food Service in 2015. ==Awards== The company was selected as [[St. Jude Children's Research Hospital|St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital]]’s “Corporate Partner of the Year” and committed to fundraise $25 million for the organization to open the St. Jude Red Frog Events [[Proton therapy|Proton Therapy]] Center.{{cite web|last1=Arnold|first1=Ed|title=St. Jude receives $25 million commitment from fundraising partner|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/memphis/news/2013/01/17/st-jude-receives-25-million.html|website=Memphis Business Journal|accessdate=17 January 2013}} * [https://www.uschamber.com/press-release/red-frog-events-named-dream-big-small-business-year-us-chamber U.S. Chamber of Commerce Small Business of the Year] * [http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2011-11-15/business/ct-biz-1115-workplaces-red-frog-20111115_1_internship-program-red-frog-events-warrior-dash Chicago Tribune Top Workplace] * [http://www.chicagoinnovationawards.com/winner/red-frog-events/ Chicago Innovation Award] * [http://www.inc.com/magazine/201209/nicole-carter/joe-reynolds-of-red-frog-events-average-joe-warrior.html Inc. 5000, Inc. Magazine, #9] * [http://www.outsideonline.com/1857136/100-best-places-work-25-1#slide-10 Outside Magazine Best Places to Work, #16] * [https://www.forbes.com/companies/red-frog-events/ Forbes Most Promising Company in America, #18] * [http://archive.101bestandbrightest.com/Portals/5/files/HR/Chicago/2015/ChicagoWinners2015.pdf 101 Best and Brightest Companies to Work For] ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Event management companies]] [[Category:Running competitions]]

revision.text:
'''Regelbau 638''': Kleiner Sanitätsunterstand<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bunkers.be/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=436&Itemid=138&lang=en|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706133150/http://www.bunkers.be/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=436&Itemid=138&lang=en|dead-url=yes|archive-date=6 July 2011|title=Typology|work=Belgian Bunkersite|accessdate=12 October 2010}}</ref>
Before and during World War II, the [[Wehrmacht]] built several standardised [[bunker]]s and weapon positions in Germany and German-occupied countries. These buildings were called [[Regelbau]], i.e. standardised buildings. This building, Regelbau 638, was a small [[field hospital]] (''Kleiner Sanitätsunterstand'').
At [[Fjell Fortress]] outside [[Bergen]] in [[Norway]] a fully restored Regelbau 638 bunker can be seen at the museum, Fjell festning. In 2009–2010 this bunker was restored inside and supplied with authentic German hospital and sanitary equipment from World War II by the local voluntary society ''Fjell Festnings Militærhistoriske Samlinger''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fjellfms.blogspot.com/2009/09/starten.html|title=Fjell Festning Militærhistoriske Samlinger: Regelbau 638|work=Fjell Festning Militærhistoriske Samlinger|publisher=[[Blogger (service)|Blogger]]|date=20 September 2009|accessdate=12 October 2010}}</ref>

{{pp-pc1}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Louisville teen sexual assault case | partof = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | location = Louisville, Kentucky | coordinates = | date = {{Start date|2011|8}} | time = | timezone = EST | type = Sexual assault | injuries = | victim = Savannah Dietrich | perpetrators= Will Frey and Austin Zehnder | dfen = | weapons = | convicted = | verdict = | convictions = | charges = sexual abuse in the first degree and voyeurism | litigation = }} In August 2011, a female American high-school student named '''Savannah Dietrich''' was [[sexual assault|sexually assaulted]] by Will Frey and Austin Zehnder, lacrosse players from [[Trinity High School (Louisville)]], an exclusive Catholic high school in [[Louisville, Kentucky]].{{cite web|author=Chinn, Valerie |url=http://www.wdrb.com/story/19428803/parents-of-juveniles-accused-of-sexual-assault-upset-that-names-are-public |title=Parents of juveniles accused of sexual assault upset that names are public |publisher=wdrb.com |date=2012-09-01 |accessdate=2016-05-18}}{{cite web|last=Pesta |first=Abigail |url=http://www.cosmopolitan.com/lifestyle/advice/a4420/cyberbullying/ |title=Fighting Back: One Girl's Mission to End Cyberbullying |publisher=Cosmopolitan.com |date=2013-06-04 |accessdate=2016-05-19}}{{cite web|author=Gye, Hugo |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2197400/Savannah-Dietrich-told-lawyer-assaulted-classmates.html |title=Savannah Dietrich was told to 'get over it' by lawyer after being assaulted by classmates | Mail Online |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2012-09-03 |accessdate=2013-01-07}} The assault was photographed by Frey and Zehnder and other observers, and images and comments from the incident went viral on the internet. In a [[plea bargain]], two 16-year-old boys Frey and Zehnder pleaded guilty to [[sexual abuse]] in the first degree, a felony, and [[voyeurism]], a misdemeanor. Dietrich released the names of her attackers and argued publicly that they were not adequately punished despite being instructed not to discuss the case by the presiding judge. International controversy regarding the case developed when attorneys for the boys attempted to have her held [[Contempt of court|in contempt]], but the motion was subsequently dropped. Afterwards, at the time of sentencing, the judge said that because of the "serious nature" of the crime, she would revise the punishment requested by the prosecutor. Accordingly, the judge removed a provision that would have [[Expungement in the United States|expunged]] the defendants' records upon reaching age {{frac|19|1|2}}, and also ordered that their [[community service]] be served at a charity that deals with women's issues.{{r|C-J}} ==Initial court proceedings, plea deal, and privacy law== The two defendants pleaded guilty to sexual abuse in the first degree, a felony and voyeurism, a misdemeanor. The initial plea-deal agreed to by the prosecutor was 50 hours of community service, a diversion agreement, counseling, and a provision to expunge the defendants' criminal records—provided they maintained good behavior—at age {{frac|19|1|2}}.{{r|WDRB}} Paul Richwalsky, the prosecutor in the case was a graduate and booster of [[Trinity High School (Louisville)]], the same school the boys attended. On June 26, 2012, Judge Deana H. McDonald admonished the parties to the case that they must follow the statutes and laws regarding privacy and confidentiality of juvenile proceedings on the Commonwealth of Kentucky.{{cite web|last=Plait |first=Phil |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/xx_factor/2012/07/23/savannah_dietrich_outs_her_rapists_on_twitter_and_facebook.html |title=Savannah Dietrich outs her rapists on Twitter and Facebook |publisher=Slate.com |date=2012-07-23 |accessdate=2013-01-07}} The state of Kentucky is one of 11 states which [[Record sealing|seal court cases]] if the accused is under 18 years of age.{{cite web|author=Chang, Juju|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/kentucky-teen-sexually-assaulted-threatened-jail-time/story?id=17005633&page=2#.UOrMGWfAUbc |title=Kentucky Teen Sexually Assaulted, Then Threatened With Jail Time - ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=2012-08-20 |accessdate=2013-01-07}} Then Judge McDonald took an extra step, indicating that the crime itself should not be discussed and that no one should "speak about the incident to anyone for any reason," she said, according to court files. "No one is to talk or type anything." This meant that Dietrich (the 16-year-old female victim) was not permitted to speak about the case, the charges, the facts and allegations therein, and the identities of the defendants.{{r|Pesta}} ==Statements by victim protesting leniency== Dietrich stated that she felt her concerns were not properly addressed and that the proposed deal was too lenient. Later that evening, she announced the names of the defendants on [[Twitter]], tweeting "Will Frey and Austin Zehnder sexually assaulted me," and "There you go, lock me up. I'm not protecting anyone that made my life a living hell." The primary judge on the case, Angela McCormick Bisig, was away the day the controversial order of silence was issued by Judge McDonald. In 2013 Judge Bisig, then a circuit-court judge, went on record acknowledging Dietrich should have been allowed to discuss the crime itself, "We cannot tell a young crime victim that they cannot tell their personal story." Attorneys for the boys attempted to have Dietrich held in contempt for publishing their names, but the motion was subsequently dropped.{{r|C-J}} Notwithstanding Judge McDonald's admonitions forbidding anyone "talk or type anything", on August 28, 2012 Judge Bisig stated in her ruling that on July 30, 2012 "Judge McDonald ruled that there was no "gag order" in place and that her admonishment had been to comply with the law of confidentiality required by Kentucky Statutes."Jefferson District Court, Juvenile Division, [http://www.rcfp.org/sites/default/files/docs/20120828_215324_courierjournal_.pdf "Opinion and Order"], p. 4 (August 28, 2012), obtained via [[Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press]]. In an affidavit, Dietrich also stated that Paul Richwalsky, the chief prosecutor in the juvenile court division, said she should "get over it and see a therapist. ... The jail was for 'real' rapists, murderers and robbers".{{r|Riley}} Richwalsky denied the allegation and stated in an affidavit "Perhaps it is not so much she is trying to intentionally mislead and deceive this court, but rather the delusional assertions made in her affidavit are merely the byproduct of what she would like to believe happened and not what in actuality took place."{{r|Riley}} ==Sentencing and revision of plea deal== During sentencing, Judge Angela Bisig emphasized the "serious nature" of the crime. She removed a provision of the plea deal that would have expunged the defendants' records when they reach age of {{frac|19|1|2}}. She also ordered that their community service be served at a charity that deals with women's issues.{{r|C-J}} Terms of the sentences require supervision by the state's juvenile justice department, offender treatment and performance of 50 hours of community service at a women's facility. After three years of good behavior the two felony charges may be amended down to misdemeanors and after five years the boys may request that the convictions be expunged.{{r|C-J}} ==Subsequent activities== Dietrich was reportedly satisfied with the revised punishment.Weiss, Jaimie. "[http://m.wave3.com/autojuice?targetUrl=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.wave3.com%2Fstory%2F19549571%2Fjudge-changes-plea-deal-after-teen-tweets-displeasure Judge changes plea deal after teen Tweets displeasure]",{{dead link|date=May 2014}} ''[[WAVE (TV)|WAVE News]]'' (September 14, 2012). In March 2013, she took an active and public role in advocating legislation in the [[Kentucky General Assembly|Kentucky legislature]], as reported by ''[[The Courier-Journal]]'':Halladay, Jessie. "Kentucky House advances bill to allow juvenile court victims to discuss case", ''[[The Courier-Journal]]'' (March 4, 2013).
[S]he hopes that a law would prevent what happened to her from happening to anyone else. She said perhaps the law will make it clear to everyone that it is the victim's right to talk about what happened.
At the same time, Dietrich indicated that such a state law is not absolutely necessary, given the protections that she believes are already afforded by the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution]]. First Amendment expert [[Eugene Volokh]] has commented about this Louisville case, saying that a pertinent [[U.S. Supreme Court]] precedent on this subject is [https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=7719461183308362244 Oklahoma Publishing v. District Court, 430 U.S. 308 (1977)]. "An order barring a victim from revealing the names of her assailants is, I think, clearly unconstitutional, even when the assailants are juveniles. Oklahoma Publishing Co. v. District Court (1977) expressly rejected the notion that courts or legislatures may bar the publication of the names of juvenile offenders; that case involved a newspaper's publishing the name of the juvenile offender, which it learned from a court hearing, but the rationale applies at least as strongly to a person's publishing a name that she learned from the attack itself."{{cite web|last=Volokh |first=Eugene |url=http://volokh.com/2012/07/22/the-dark-side-of-privacy/ |title=The Dark Side of Privacy |publisher=The Volokh Conspiracy |date=2012-07-22 |accessdate=2016-05-20}} ==See also== *[[Rape in the United States]] *[[Steubenville High School rape case]] *[[Torrington High School rape case]] ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite news|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2012/12/09/thanks-for-ruining-my-life.html|title='Thanks for Ruining My Life'|last=Pesta|first=Abigail|date=December 10, 2012|work=Newsweek|publisher=The Daily Beast|accessdate=3 January 2013}} {{cite news|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20120914/NEWS01/101070010/0/NEWS/Savannah-Dietrich-attackers-get-slightly-tougher-sentence?gcheck=1&nclick_check=1|title=Savannah Dietrich attackers get slightly tougher sentence|last=Riley|first=Jason|date=September 15, 2012|work=[[The Courier-Journal]]|publisher=Wes Jackson|accessdate=9 August 2013|location=Louisville, Kentucky}} {{cite web|url=http://www.wdrb.com/story/19545645/savannah-dietrich|title=Savannah Dietrich comes face-to-face with admitted abusers|date=September 19, 2012|publisher=WDRB|accessdate=4 January 2013|location=Louisville, Kentucky}} {{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/nation/story/2012-08-31/teens-thought-sex-asssault-funny/57488766/1|title=Teens who assaulted 16-year-old thought it would be 'funny'|last=Riley|first=Jason|author2=Wolfson, Andrew |date=August 31, 2012|work=[[USA Today]]|publisher=[[Gannett]]|accessdate=4 January 2013|location=Louisville, Kentucky}} }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dietrich, Savannah}} [[Category:2011 crimes in the United States]] [[Category:Crimes in Louisville, Kentucky]] [[Category:Rapes in the United States]] [[Category:Crimes against children]] [[Category:2011 in Kentucky]] [[Category:Incidents of violence against women]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} :''Not to be confused with the [[Soundwave (Australian Music Festival)|Soundwave Festival]] in Australia {{Infobox music festival | name =Soundwave Biennial Festival | image = | caption = | location =[[San Francisco]], [[California]] | years_active =2004-present | founders =MEDIATE Art Group | dates =Every two years for two months | genre = [[Electronic music]], art | attendance = | capacity = | website = [http://www.soundwaveSF.com/ Soundwave Festival site] }} '''Soundwave Biennial Festival''' (formerly called the '''Soundwave Series''') is a sound, art, and music festival that happens every two years for two months in San Francisco.<ref name="flavorpill1">{{cite web |author=Various locations says… |url=http://flavorpill.com/sanfrancisco/events/2008/6/27/move-sound-sound-wave-series-3 |title=MOVE>SOUND: Soundwave>Series 3 @ Various locations – Flavorpill San Francisco |publisher=Flavorpill.com |date=27 June 2008 |accessdate=20 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111003093015/http://flavorpill.com/sanfrancisco/events/2008/6/27/move-sound-sound-wave-series-3 |archivedate=3 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Overview== Soundwave is produced by the 501(c)3 non-profit Mediate Art Group. The festival features diverse local and international multimedia artists working with sound including noise artists, sound artists, improvisers, experimental musicians, composers, avant-garde musicians, vocalists, [[Electroacoustic music|electroacoustic]] musicians, classical musicians and rock musicians. The festival focuses on new and unusual performances and art works, often in untraditional environments. Soundwave primarily showcases "sound art," but also explores disciplines such as media art, performance art, music, dance, and installation. It’s an art experience out of the unexpected to explore important ideas and issues of our time.
==Artists== Soundwave created the well-received<ref name="synthtopia1">{{cite web|url=http://www.synthtopia.com/content/2009/11/24/twitter-goddess-zoe-keating-blows-peoples-minds-with-a-cello-on-a-bus/ |title=Twitter Goddess Zoe Keating Blows People’s Minds, With A Cello, On A Bus |publisher=Synthtopia |date=24 November 2009 |accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="academik1">{{cite web|url=http://www.academik.org/2008/07/20/the-audiobus-one-of-those-rare-life-doesnt-get-any-better-than-this-moments/ |title=The Audiobus: One of those rare ‘life doesn’t get any better than this’ moments |publisher=Academik |date=20 July 2008 |accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref> AudioBus series conceived by Soundwave founder and artistic director Alan So for its third season MOVE SOUND in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jennifer Maerz |url=http://www.sfweekly.com/2008-07-02/music/soundwave-s-audiobus-series-offers-road-trips-with-local-composers/ |title=Soundwave's AudioBus series offers road trips with local composers – Page 1 – Music |work=SF Weekly |date=2 July 2008 |accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref> It featured Bay Area singer [[Goh Nakamura]],<ref name="academik1"/><ref>{{cite web |last=Mac |first=Vicki |url=http://www.asianweek.com/2008/07/28/goh-on-the-bus-sf-troubadour-takes-show-on-the-road/ |title=Goh on the Bus: SF Troubadour Takes Show on the Road |publisher=Asianweek.com |date=29 July 2008 |accessdate=20 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629121905/http://www.asianweek.com/2008/07/28/goh-on-the-bus-sf-troubadour-takes-show-on-the-road/ |archivedate=29 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> avant-cellist [[Zoe Keating]],<ref name="synthtopia1"/> [[Odessa Chen]] and [ruidobello] and David Graves.<ref>{{cite web|author=Photo: Katy Raddatz / The Chronicle |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/object/article?f=/c/a/2008/07/10/NS0211J3BD.DTL&o=0 |title=Sound artist David Graves (pictured – Media (1 of 1) 'Resonance' and AudioBus: Experience sound |work=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref>
Other noted artists and musicians that have created performances at Soundwave include: [[Moe! Staiano]] (Moe!Kestra!), [[Andrea Polli]], [[Matt Davignon]], [[Diana Burgoyne]], ([[Rob Reger]] (Beno+Minnie with Aimee Friberg), Dana Gumbiner (of [[Deathray]] under electronic name Night Night), Danny Grody (of [[Tarentel (band)|Tarentel]] performing with band The Drift) and Neal Morgan (of [[Joanna Newsom]]'s Y Street Band and [[Golden Shoulders]])
Soundwave was awarded "Best Sound Sculptures – Future Classic" by the editors of [[San Francisco Magazine]] in their Best of 2007 issue<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.me-di-ate.net/releases/SFmag0807.html |title=NEWS |publisher=Mediate |date=15 August 2007 |accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref> while being compared to San Francisco's [[Audium (Theater)]].
==Soundwave seasons== Soundwave has had seven seasons: FREE SOUND 2004, SURROUND SOUND 2006 (curator and show featured by SPARK* on [[KQED (TV)|KQED]]-PBS),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kqed.org/arts/programs/spark/profile.jsp?essid=8663 |title=Matt Davignon: Spark |publisher=KQED |date=14 October 2011 |accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref> MOVE SOUND 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebaybridged.com/2008/06/23/movesound/ |title=Soundwave>Series ((3)) Takes Place June 27 to August 17 : The Bay Bridged – San Francisco Bay Area Indie Music |publisher=Thebaybridged.com |date=23 June 2008 |accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="flavorpill1"/> which included amplified skateboarding,<ref>{{cite web|author=Silke Tudor |url=http://www.sfweekly.com/2008-06-25/calendar/the-grindermen/ |title=The Grindermen – Page 1 – Calendar |work=SF Weekly |date=25 June 2008 |accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref> sound drawing,<ref>{{cite web |last=Maxwell |first=Leanne |url=http://sfist.com/2008/06/27/soundwaveseries_3_envirosonic.php |title=Soundwave>Series 3: EnviroSonic Tonight |publisher=SFist |date=27 June 2008 |accessdate=20 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001192921/http://sfist.com/2008/06/27/soundwaveseries_3_envirosonic.php |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> holographic movies.<ref>[http://bcnm.berkeley.edu/blog/2008/08/hologlyphic-movies-at-projectsoundwave-series-berkeley-ca-080108/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090822075108/http://bcnm.berkeley.edu/blog/2008/08/hologlyphic-movies-at-projectsoundwave-series-berkeley-ca-080108/ |date=22 August 2009 }}</ref> ME'DI.ATE's fourth Soundwave season GREEN SOUND 2010 included performances in historic WWII Bunkers,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kqed.org/arts/music/article.jsp?essid=30044 |title=Soundwave Festival: Music |publisher=KQED |accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref> churches,<ref>{{cite web|author=Michael Leaverton |url=http://www.sfweekly.com/2010-06-02/calendar/sounding-good/ |title=Sounding Good – Page 1 – Calendar |work=SF Weekly |date=2 June 2010 |accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref> city streets and parks, and an artist-imagined environment Illuminated Forest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.treehugger.com/files/2010/07/sf-artists-explore-what-green-sounds-like.php |title=SF Artists Explore What 'Green' Sounds Like |publisher=TreeHugger |accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref> Its fifth season Soundwave HUMANITIES 2012 has been called [https://web.archive.org/web/20120710104411/http://flavorpill.com/sanfrancisco/events/2012/7/5/soundwave-5 epic], [http://www.sfbg.com/2012/07/03/kinda-cyborgy glorious] and with [http://blogs.sfweekly.com/exhibitionist/2012/07/soundwave_cal_academy_nightlife.php distinct and daring] artists. Season six explored WATER in 2014 in the midst of a California drought. The seventh season ARCHITECTURE<ref>{{cite web|last1=Zaldua|first1=Chris|title=At Soundwave, Listening to a Changing Cityscape|url=https://ww2.kqed.org/arts/2016/06/30/at-soundwave-listening-to-a-changing-cityscape/|website=kqed.org|publisher=KQED|accessdate=31 December 2017}}</ref> occurred in 2016 exploring the rapid transformation of San Francisco's changing cityscapes and its implications. Its eight season in 2018 is INFRASTRUCTURE exploring Bay Area and global networks provoking ideas around isolation amid interconnectivity; environmental degradation and mass consumption of electronics; the politics of energy infrastructures, fossil fuels and renewables; the movement of goods and services across roads, bridges, railways, channels and ports; the often invisible protocols that affect our daily lives.
==Locations== Soundwave events have occurred in galleries, museums, and unusual and iconic locations in and around San Francisco. They have included: * Grace Cathedral<ref>{{cite web|last1=Escobar|first1=Claudia|title=Sacred Voyage: When ‘Soundwave’ First Came to the Grace Cathedral|url=https://ww2.kqed.org/arts/2016/09/09/sacred-voyage-when-soundwave-first-came-to-the-grace-cathedral/|website=kqed.org|publisher=KQED|accessdate=31 December 2017}}</ref> * California Academy of Sciences * de Young Museum * Legion of Honor * Battery Townsley<ref>{{cite web|last1=Swanson|first1=Charlie|title=Waves of Sound|url=https://www.bohemian.com/northbay/waves-of-sound/Content?oid=2604551|website=www.bohemian.com|publisher=North Bay Bohemian|accessdate=31 December 2017}}</ref> * San Francisco Zen Center<ref>{{cite web|last1=sperry|first1=rod|title=Music and meditation go hand in hand at San Francisco Zen Center|url=https://www.lionsroar.com/music-and-meditation-go-hand-in-hand-at-san-francisco-zen-center/|website=www.lionsroar.com|publisher=Lion's Roar|accessdate=31 December 2017}}</ref> * California College of the Arts * San Francisco Art Institute * Dolby Cinema * SPUR * The Exploratorium * Yerba Buena Gardens * Civic Center Plaza<ref>{{cite web|title=Inflorescence|url=http://www.projectsoundwave.com/4/2010/june17/|website=Project>Soundwave|publisher=MEDIATE}}</ref> * Ocean Beach * The Lab * Alterspace * Contemporary Jewish Museum * Gray Area Foundation for the Arts * Intersection for the Arts
==See also== *[[List of electronic music festivals]] *[[Experimental rock]]
==References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using<ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically -->
{{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.projectsoundwave.com/ Soundwave Festival site] * [http://www.me-di-ate.net/ ME'DI.ATE Art Group] {{Electronic music festival}} [[Category:Music festivals established in 2004]] [[Category:Festivals in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Music festivals in California]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2004]] [[Category:2004 establishments in California]] [[Category:Electronic music festivals in the United States]] [[Category:Electroacoustic music festivals]]

revision.text:
[[Image:SurfCarnivalMarchOfStanwellPark.jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[Nippers]] marching at a ''surf carnival''.]] [[Image:SurfBoatCompetitionAtIllawarraCarnival.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Surf boat competition during a ''surf carnival''.]] In Australian culture sports carnivals are held to perform competitions in the individual or team disciplines like athletics, swimming or [[Surf Life Saving]]. Teams from different clubs or schools gather together for both individual point-score and team score. Often, the carnival is opened by a parade with the teams marching in uniforms and flags over the field of competition.
==Surf carnival==
[[Surf Life Saving Club]]s in [[Australia]] train their [[nippers]] and young [[surf lifesaving|life savers]] for competitions in ''surf carnivals''. Local, regional, state and nationwide competitions are held across the country. Junior carnivals compete for age groups starting from under-8 to under-14, while senior competitions among active surf life savers start from under-15 to ''veterans''. Veterans are athletes 30 years and older; the age groups are in 5-year blocks: 30–34, 35–39, 40–44, all the way up to 65+. Surf boat competitions start from 16+.
==See also== * [[Sports day]] * [[The Coolangatta Gold]]
==References== * [http://www.nma.gov.au/exhibitions/now_showing/between_the_flags/competition_in_the_surf/ National Museum of Australia - Surf Competitions] * [http://www.mediaman.com.au/articles/the_surf_carnival.html The Surf Carnival, by Ross Renwick] * [http://www.waverley.nsw.gov.au/library/localstudies/historical/carnival.htm Bronte's first Surf Carnival] * [http://www.slsa.com.au/default.aspx?s=yearofthesurflifesaver 2007 - Year of the Surf Life Saver] * [http://www.aussies2007.com/en/default.htm Aussies 2007 - National Surf Competitions] * [http://www.jla.gr.jp/isrc2013/ The 2013 International Surf Rescue Challenge, [[Onjuku,_Chiba|Onjuku Beach]]]
[[Category:Sport in Australia]] [[Category:Multi-sport events]] [[Category:Surf lifesaving]] [[Category:Carnivals]] [[Category:Sports festivals in Australia]]

{{Infobox Magazine| title = Spremnost | image = | editor = [[Ivo Bogdan]] (beginning of 1942)
[[Tias Mortigjija]] (from May 1942 until [[Christmas]] 1944)
[[Franjo Nevistić]] (from Christmas 1944 until breakdown in 1945) | frequency = weekly | category = [[Newsmagazine]] | company = Ustaški nakladni zavod | founded = 1942 | finaldate = 1945 | country = [[Independent State of Croatia]] | language = [[Croatian language|Croatian]] | website = | issn = }} '''''Spremnost''''' was a weekly [[newsmagazine]] of former [[Ustaše|Ustaše movement]] from [[Zagreb]], that has written about everything, politics, war, economy and culture. Magazine was published from the beginning of 1942 until breakdown of the [[Independent State of Croatia]] in May 1945. ==Founding and breakdown== Since the establishment of the [[Independent State of Croatia]] the leading Croatian dailies, have become; ''Hrvatski narod'' and ''Nova Hrvatska'', the leading ideological weekly newspaper of general type was ''Spremnost''. Other newspapers that are coming out then were; weekly humorous magazine ''Šilo'', newspapers ''Gospodarstvo'' (Economic Affairs), ''Hrvatski radnik'', ''Plug'', ''Plava revija'', ''Hrvatska revija'' and ''Vienac''. Newsmagazine ''Spremnost'' was initiated only when the [[Ustaše|Ustaša regime]] mastered the methods of total control of the press. The initiator and main organizer was [[Ivo Bogdan]] and chief editor was [[Tias Mortigjija]] (until 1944). In addition with Mortigjija and Bogdan, in magazine regularly publish articles on politics; Milivoj Magdić, [[Savić Marković Štedimlija|Savić Štedimlija]] and [[Ante Ciliga]] (since 1943). Magdić was responsible for the critique of [[Marxism–Leninism]], Štedimlija was some kind of specialist in [[Balkans]] issues, especially for the ''[[Chetniks|Chetnik movement]]'', and Ciliga wrote about the [[Soviet Union]] (he was spent in [[Russia]] about 10 years). Other important collaborators were: [[Ljubomir Maraković]] (literature), Ton Smerdel, Radoslav Glavaš, Albert Haler, [[Antun Barac]] and Mihovil Kombol. Overall ''Spremnost'' was a typical puppet news magazine of this time with a strong nationalistic note, - defended the policy of its [[Axis powers|sponsors]], and critical writing about politics of [[Allies of World War II|Allies]] tried to show his politics as disastrous for Europe. Allies are generally portrayed as unnatural interest coalition of ''[[Jews]], [[Freemasonry]] and [[Communists]]''. Thus, to illustrate the ''Spremnost'' published on 13 September 1942. Ivo Bogdan article that says that the [[Independent State of Croatia]] must resist »the Jews, freemasons, communists«, as internal enemies, with »courage, determination and political foresight«.[http://www.vjesnik.hr/html/2004/04/22/Clanak.asp?r=sta&c=2 Ivo Horvat: Ne može se rehabilitirati novinstvo koje je služilo totalitarističkoj politici i praksi ustaškoga režima (22. travnja 2004.), Vjesnik online (Accessed: september 2, 2010) {{hr icon}}]{{dead link|date=December 2014}} Even when it was clear that the Axis powers have lost the war - the Allied successes were depicted in an entirely different light, or are completely minimized. In this light is described [[Allied invasion of Sicily]] - as a completely insignificant event, which does not have any military significance in relation to the main east front.[http://szi-humanistika.ffzg.hr/webpac/?rm=results&show_full=1&f=UncontrolledTerms&v=tjednik%20 O tjedniku Spremnost, Knjižnice Filozofskog fakulteta, Sveučilišta u Zagrebu (Accessed: september 2, 2010) {{hr icon}}]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == Literature == *Macan, Trpimir, Bogišić, Vlaho i drugi: ''Spremnost : 1942-1945'', Zagreb : Matica hrvatska, 1998 godina, {{ISBN|953-150-161-0}} {{hr icon}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Defunct magazines of Croatia]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1942]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 1945]] [[Category:Media in Zagreb]] [[Category:News magazines]] [[Category:Weekly magazines]] [[Category:Croatian-language magazines]] [[Category:Fascist newspapers and magazines]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} [[File:Superkart.JPG|thumb|upright=1.4|A Formula E/Division 250 cc Superkart at [[Castle Combe Circuit|Castle Combe]], England.]] '''Superkart''' is a form of [[motorsport]] [[road racing]] in which the class is a racing vehicle sized like a [[kart]] but with several characteristics more strongly associated with [[Open wheel car|open-wheel racing cars]].
The most obvious difference between a Superkart and any other form of kart is that they have full aerodynamic bodykits and can race on car circuits over 1,500 metres in length. The power unit, most often, but not exclusively [[Two-stroke engine|two stroke]] 250 cc engines, can be specially designed kart engines or production motorcycle engines with either five or six-speed sequential gearboxes. Owing to their high top speed and superb cornering ability, a Superkart's [[aerodynamic]] [[Car body style|bodywork]] includes a front [[Kart fairing|fairing]], larger [[sidepod]]s, and a [[Spoiler (automotive)|rear wing]]. They use either {{convert|5|or|6|in|mm|adj=mid|-diameter}} [[tire]]s and [[wheel]]s and most often race on full size auto-racing circuits.
250 cc Superkarts often{{quantify|date=October 2012}} set faster lap times than much more expensive and technically advanced racing machines.<ref name="magny">[http://www.mediasuperkart.com/en/news-actualite-313-french-cup-superkart-a-magny-cours.html Magny Cours F1 - Superkarts fire the crowds imagination !!] - 6 July 2007</ref><ref name="roadandtrack">[http://www.roadandtrack.com/racing/motorsports/superkarts-super-speeds Superkarts — Super Speeds] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111106122037/http://www.roadandtrack.com/racing/motorsports/superkarts-super-speeds |date=6 November 2011 }} - ''Road & Track'', November 2005</ref> Some British and Australian classes also include 125 cc gearbox karts.
Superkarts race on "long circuits"<ref>[http://www.cikfia.com/fileadmin/content/REGULATIONS/Circuits/Circuits%20Regulations/2011%20Circuit%20Regulations%20Parts%201%20&%202.pdf CIK-FIA 2011 circuit regulation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110626114909/http://www.cikfia.com/fileadmin/content/REGULATIONS/Circuits/Circuits%20Regulations/2011%20Circuit%20Regulations%20Parts%201%20%26%202.pdf |date=26 June 2011 }} - [[Commission Internationale de Karting|CIK-FIA]], Part 1: Article 6</ref> (e.g. [[Silverstone Circuit|Silverstone]], [[Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca|Laguna Seca]], [[Circuit de Nevers Magny-Cours|Magny-Cours]]). In the UK they also race on "short circuits"<ref>[http://www.karting.co.uk/tstp/RaceResults.asp?RS=1252&RE=10001&RC=18092 Race results & reports for all gearbox classes - 8 July 2007 - Kimbolton]</ref> (e.g. [[Kimbolton Kart Club|Kimbolton]]), "short circuits" are under 1,500 metres in length.<ref>[http://www.emamc.org.uk/archive/2007/Blue_Book/338-356_Sec_N_-_Karting.pdf Specific Regulations for Karting] - [[Motor Sports Association]] (MSA), Circuits</ref>
Superkarts are raced worldwide. There is a multi-event [[FIA|CIK-FIA]] European Superkart Championship (for 250 cc karts only),<ref>[http://www.cikfia.com/fileadmin/content/REGULATIONS/Technical/Technical%20Regulations/2011%20Technical%20Regulations.pdf CIK-FIA 2011 Karting Technical Regulations] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928143658/http://www.cikfia.com/fileadmin/content/REGULATIONS/Technical/Technical%20Regulations/2011%20Technical%20Regulations.pdf |date=28 September 2011 }} - [[Commission Internationale de Karting|CIK-FIA]], Article 9: Specific Regulations for Superkart</ref> and there has in the past been a World Championship, which was last run in 1995.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mondial-karting.com/250cc/2004/champions.htm |title=CIK-FIA European & World Champions in Superkart 250cc |publisher=http://www.mondial-karting.com |accessdate=29 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110909082405/http://www.mondial-karting.com/250cc/2004/champions.htm |archivedate=9 September 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Performance== Powered by a [[2-stroke]] 250 cc engine producing 62 [[horsepower|hp]] for an overall weight including the driver of 205 kilograms, Superkarts have a [[Power-to-weight ratio|power/weight ratio]] of 440 hp/[[tonne]] (330 W/kg)(c.5 lbs/hp). Superkarts can accelerate from 0 to 60 mph in less than 3 seconds with a top speed of 155 mph (250 km/h).<ref>[http://www.parcferme.com/content/view/2663/2/ Superkart at Magny-Cours - 2007]</ref> Their low weight and good [[downforce]] make for excellent cornering<ref>''"Yeah, I can take that right-hander flat-out in 6th gear at just shy of 120 mph." When my face shows disbelief (120 mph?!), he adds, "It moves around a little, but you just keep your foot in it. The rear wing is producing good downforce there and it will hold."'' — [[Eddie Lawson]] - [http://www.roadandtrack.com/article.asp?section_id=21&article_id=2827 Superkart Thrill Ride, page 1] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060127222725/http://www.roadandtrack.com/article.asp?section_id=21&article_id=2827 |date=27 January 2006 }} - Road & Track,October 2005</ref> and braking abilities.<ref>''"The biggest adjustment compared to cars or even other karts is the speed with which this kart enters turns and how late I can brake for them. Its ability to shed speed is right up there with many open-wheel race cars. Braking is performed in a straighter line than with a rear brake-only sprint kart, though the rate of deceleration is considerably greater."'' - [http://www.roadandtrack.com/article.asp?section_id=21&article_id=2827&page_number=2 Superkart Thrill Ride, page 2]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} - Road & Track,October 2005</ref> A Superkart is capable of braking from 100 mph (160 km/h) to standstill in around 2 seconds, and taking corners at nearly 3 ''[[g-force|''g'']]'' (30 m/s²).<ref>[https://archive.is/20120906220216/http://www.qldsuperkart.org/?q=taxonomy/term/12 Performance ; 250cc International] - Queensland Superkart Club</ref>
At some circuits, Superkarts are the outright lap-record holders,<ref>[http://www.morganparkraceway.com.au/records.htm Morgan Park Raceway Lap Records] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090107022421/http://www.morganparkraceway.com.au/records.htm |date=7 January 2009 }}</ref> at others they run at around [[Formula 3]] lap times.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} [[File:Ben Willshire GP1.jpg|thumb|right|Ben Wilshire British 125 Open class Superkart]] '''British Superkart Divisions''' : {{main|British Superkart Championship}} *'''Division 1''' is open to 250 cc karts with one or two cylinders and five or six speed gearboxes. Typically the karts produce 100 hp and are capable of 160 mph - the fastest form of kart. This formula was previously known as Formula E, which was changed to avoid confusion with the [[Formula E]] series. *'''Division 2''' is for single cylinder karts with 5 and 6-speed boxes. Typically these karts produce 65 hp and are capable of 140 mph. However, being lighter than the twin cylinder (Division 1) karts they can be as quick on twisted circuits. This formula was previously known as 250 International. However the main British series is for single cylinder 250 cc karts with 5-speed only, also known as 250 National. *'''125 Open''' - Powered by 125 cc engines and again featuring 6-speed sequential gearboxes, this [[Kart racing#Sprint|sprint kart]] class uses lighter chassis than the 250's. *'''125 ICC (KZ)''' - Powered by similar 6-speed 125 cc engines to the 125 Open class with tighter tuning restrictions, this CIK [[Kart racing#Sprint|sprint kart]] class hosts some of the closest Superkart racing in the UK. [[File:Mcilveen.jpg|thumb|right|2007 Australian 250 cc International champion Warren McIlveen (Stockman-Honda)]] '''Australian Superkart Classes''':<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.superkartsaustralia.org/ |title=Superkarts Australia: Superkarts Classes |publisher=Superkarts Australia }}</ref><ref name="CAMS">{{cite web |url=http://camsmanual.com.au/pdf/01_about/AC07_Titles_Australian_Q211.pdf |title=2011 CAMS Manual of Motor Sport: Australian Titles |year=2011 |work= |publisher=[[Confederation of Australian Motor Sport|CAMS]] |pages=13–14 |format=PDF |accessdate=29 June 2011}}</ref> {{main|Australian Superkart Championship}}
Superkarting in Australia has, since 1989, referred to any form of racing kart to race on full-size motor racing circuits, usually as sanctioned by the Australian ASN, [[Confederation of Australian Motor Sport|CAMS]]. *'''250 cc International''' - commonly referred to as ''twins'' or ''inters'', these karts are powered by twin cylinder engines and usually have 6-speed sequential gearboxes. Several European and North American chassis are popular in addition to locally developed designs. *'''250 cc National''' - single cylinder class, the 250 National class is powered by 250 cc [[motocross]] engines and also feature 6-speed sequential gearboxes. *'''125 cc Gearbox''' - most often powered by 125 cc Honda and Yamaha Grand Prix motorcycle engines equipped with six speed sequential gearboxes, this Superkart class uses mostly the same chassis as the 250 classes. They run at lighter weights than the 250 classes, which makes for close racing with mid-field 250 Nationals at some circuits. *'''80 cc Gearbox''' - also dominated by Honda and Yamaha motor cycle engines, 80 cc gearbox Superkarts is no longer a sanctioned class in Australian racing. Some 80 cc karts were noticeably smaller than 125/250 cc gearbox karts, with 'laydown' style karts, where the driver lies flat in the kart rather than sitting upright, proliferating. Last contested at national level in 2005.<ref name="CAMS"/> and state level in 2008, some 80 cc karts survive racing in the 125 cc division at state level, but are uncompetitive as they no longer run at lighter homologated weight levels. *'''125 cc [[Rotax Max]]''' - a cross-over class from Australian short-circuit non-gearbox [[Kart racing#Sprint|sprint kart racing]] to allow easier and cheaper graduation from Sprint karting to long circuit racing. Three national championships exist for two weight divisions, '''Heavy''' and '''Light''', and also sometimes a '''Junior''' division for drivers under the age of sixteen which run a version of the Rotax Max engine without a power valve. Rotax Max karts frequently race amongst gearbox equipped Superkarts at state championship level, while racing for their own titles at national level.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.camsmanual.com.au/sportregs/2011_Aust_Non-Gearbox_Superkart_Nationals_SportRegs-1.pdf |title=2011 Australian Non Gearbox Superkart Nationals: Sporting Regulations |publisher=[[Confederation of Australian Motor Sport|CAMS]] |format=PDF |accessdate=29 June 2011}}</ref> *'''100 cc''' Another non-gearbox class, 100 cc also was split into Heavy, Light and Junior classes, and was last contested in 2002 and has since been replaced completely by Rotax Max.<ref name="CAMS"/>
'''United States Superkart Classes''':<ref>[http://www.theussk.com/ United States SuperKarts - USSK]</ref> [[File:Superkart-With-250cc-Shifter-Kart-Motor.jpg|thumb|[https://gokartsrock.com/125-shifter-engines-125cc-shifter-engine/ 250cc Shifter Kart]]]
*'''250 cc Formula/E or F/E''' - Twin cylinder, 6-speed, liquid cooled Grand Prix motorcycle engines such as the Honda RS250, Yamaha TZ250 or made for karting engines such as the BRC250. *'''250 cc Inter-Continental E or IC/E''' - Single cylinder, 5 or 6-speed, liquid cooled Grand Prix motorcycle engines.
==Spectacle== {{original research|section|date=October 2012}} ''[[Road & Track]]'' reports Supercart to cost between $15,000 to $20,000 USD in 2005.<ref name="roadandtrack"/> Entries of 60 or more are common in Britain. Overtaking tends to be easy, as there is room to get past, so the races tend to be full of action. Race lengths tend to be around 20–25 miles (30–40 km), because the fuel tanks are quite small, so at most meetings which feature Superkarts, the karts race is often a brief, spectacular highlight (U.S. Superkart races are a timed 30-minute race; Pre-Final on Saturday, Final on Sunday).
A global category, Superkarts are endorsed by the [[FIA]], and were featured as a support category to the [[French Grand Prix|French Formula 1 Grand Prix]] at [[Circuit de Nevers Magny-Cours|Magny-Cours]] in 2007 where they bettered [[Porsche Supercup]] lap times.<ref name="magny"/>
==See also== * [[Kart circuits]] * [[KZ1 (karting)|KZ1]] * [[KZ2]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{dmoz|/Sports/Motorsports/Karting/Shifter_Karts/}} * [http://www.cikfia.com CIK-FIA - International Karting Governing Body] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110928143734/http://www.cikfia.com/fileadmin/content/REGULATIONS/Sporting/Sporting%20Regulations/17_2011%20Euro%20Superkart%20Sporting%20Regulations.pdf 2011 Euro Superkart Sporting Regulations] - [[Commission Internationale de Karting|CIK-FIA]] * [http://www.superkart.org.uk BSA - British Superkart Association] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080701142059/http://www.cikfia.com/web/karting/webkarting.nsf/results?openview&Collapse=all 1990 - 2007 CIK Results]

revision.text:
{{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} {{nihongo|'''''Tango no Sekku'''''|端午の節句}} also known as ''Ayame no hi'' (Iris festival) is one the five annual ceremonies that were traditionally held at the Japanese imperial court called [[Gosekku]] . It is the Japanese version of [[Double Fifth]] and was celebrated on the fifth day of the fifth moon in the [[lunar calendar]] or [[Chinese calendar]]. After Japan switched to the [[Gregorian calendar]], the date was moved to [[May 5]].<ref name="nussbaum948">Nussbaum, Louis Frédéric ''et al'' (2005). "Tango no Sekku" in {{Google books|p2QnPijAEmEC|''Japan Encyclopedia'', pp. 948.|page=948}}</ref> The festival is still celebrated in [[China]], [[Taiwan]], [[Hong Kong]] and [[Macau]] as the [[Duanwu Festival]] or Tuen Ng Festival (Cantonese), in Korea as the [[Dano (Korean festival)|Dano Festival]], and Vietnam as the [[Tết Đoan Ngọ]] on the traditional lunar calendar date.
{{nihongo||端|Tan}} means "beginning" and {{nihongo||[[wikt:午|午]]|go}} is a simplified form of ⾺ ([[Horse (zodiac)|horse]]), referring to the [[Chinese zodiac#Months and solar terms|Chinese zodiac name]] for the fifth lunar month. Days of the week also have zodiac animals. Thus, ''tango'' originally meant "the first horse day of the fifth month". However, ''go'' is a [[homonym]] for 五 (five) in Japanese, so during the [[Nara period]] the meaning shifted to become the fifth day of the fifth month.<ref name=ningyo>{{cite web|title=端午の節句と5月人形|trans-title=Tango no sekku and May dolls|language=ja|url=http://www.ningyo-kyokai.or.jp/sekku/tango.html|publisher=Japanese Doll Association|accessdate=7 May 2014}}</ref> ''Sekku'' means a seasonal festival. There are five ''sekku'', including [[shogatsu|O-Shogatsu]] (January 1), [[hinamatsuri|Hina Matsuri]] (March 3), [[Tanabata]] (July 7) and [[Chrysanthemum Day|Kiku Matsuri]] (September 9th) along with Tango. ''Tango no Sekku'' marks the beginning of [[summer]] or the [[rainy season]].
==History== [[Image:Japanese Festival in Honor of the Birth of Children.jpg|left|thumb|"Japanese Festival in Honor of the Birth of Children" from ''Sketches of Japanese Manners and Customs'', by J.M.W. Silver, illustrated by native drawings, published in London in 1867]] Although it is not known precisely when this day started to be celebrated, it was probably during the reign of the [[Empress Suiko]] (593–628 A.D.). In [[Japan]], ''Tango no Sekku'' was assigned to the fifth day of the fifth month after the [[Nara period]].
Until recently, ''Tango no Sekku'' was known as '''Boys' Day''' (also known as '''Feast of Banners''') while Girls' Day (''[[Hinamatsuri]]'') was celebrated on March 3. In 1948, the government decreed this day to be a national holiday to celebrate the happiness of all children and to express gratitude toward mothers. It was renamed ''[[Kodomo no Hi]]'' (Children's Day) and changed to include both boys and girls.
Before this day, families raise the [[carp]]-shaped ''[[koinobori]]'' flags (carp because of the Chinese legend that a carp that swims upstream becomes a dragon, and the way the flags blow in the wind looks like they are swimming), one for each boy (or child), display a [[Kintarō]] [[Japanese traditional dolls|doll]] usually riding on a large carp, and the traditional Japanese military helmet, ''[[kabuto]]''. Kintarō and the ''kabuto'' are symbols of a strong and healthy boy.
{{nihongo|Kintarō|金太郎}} is the childhood name of ''Sakata no Kintoki'' who was a hero in the [[Heian period]], a subordinate samurai of [[Yorimitsu Minamoto|Minamoto no Raikou]], having been famous for his strength when he was a child. It is said that Kintarō rode a [[bear]], instead of a [[horse]], and played with animals in the mountains when he was a young boy.
''[[Mochi]]'' rice cakes wrapped in ''kashiwa'' ([[oak]]) leaves—''kashiwa-mochi'' (''mochi'' filled with [[red bean paste|red bean jam]]) and ''chimaki'' (a kind of "sweet rice paste", wrapped in an iris or bamboo leaf)—are traditionally served on this day.
== See also == * [[Aging of Japan]] * [[Children's Day (Japan)]] * [[Double Fifth]] * [[Golden Week (Japan)|Golden Week]] * [[Hinamatsuri|Momo no Sekku]] * [[Tết Đoan Ngọ]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Nussbaum, Louis Frédéric and Käthe Roth. (2005). ''Japan Encyclopedia.'' Cambridge: [[Harvard University Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-674-01753-5}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/48943301/editions?editionsView=true&referer=br OCLC 48943301]
==External links== {{Wikisource1911Enc|Banners, Feast of}} * [http://web-japan.org/kidsweb/explore/calendar/may/children.html Kids Web Japan] {{Wikisource1911Enc|Banners, Feast of}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FHznlNbpdms Video on Children Day in Fukushima, Japan] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yoilg-mtEKw Video on Children Day in Coffs Harbour, Australia]

{{unreferenced|date=April 2015}} {{Italic title}} '''''Theatre World''''' first published in 1945, is the only comprehensive, annual pictorial and statistical record of [[United States|American]] theatre in print publication, including [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], [[Off-Broadway]], [[Off-Off-Broadway]], and [[Regional theater in the United States|regional theatre]], as well as a complete national theatrical awards section and obituaries. Including over 750 photographs, it is the definitive pictorial and statistical reference to each American theatrical season, and is referenced daily by industry professionals, students, historians, and theatre fans worldwide.
Until 1998, the ''Theatre World'' editorial staff administered the [[Theatre World Award]]s for Outstanding Broadway and off-Broadway debuts. First under the supervision of ''Theatre World'' founder Daniel Blum and then under [[John A. Willis|John Willis]], who took over the production of the Awards following Blum's death in 1964, the Theatre World Awards were first given to those recipients considered "Promising Personalities." In 1998, the Theatre World Awards were incorporated as a [[501(c)|501 (c) 3]] nonprofit organization and are currently overseen by a board of directors independent of "Theatre World."
''Theatre World'' is the recipient of a 2001 [[Tony Honors for Excellence in Theatre|Tony Honor for Excellence in Theatre]], presented by the [[American Theatre Wing]], and on behalf of the publication, longtime editor-in-chief [[John A. Willis|John Willis]] (1916-2010) accepted honors including the first Special [[Lucille Lortel Award]], a Special [[Drama Desk Award]], and the Broadway Theatre Institute (now [[The Theatre Museum]]) Lifetime Achievement Award.
''Theatre World'' is published annually by Theatre World Media and distributed by [[Hal Leonard Corporation|Applause Theatre and Cinema Books]]. The permanent editorial staff currently consists of Ben Hodges, editor in chief, and coeditor Scott Denny. Current editorial staff includes Adam Feldman of ''[[Time Out New York]]'' (Broadway), Linda Buchwald [[Theatre Development Fund|TDF Stages]] (Off-Broadway), Shay Gines [[New York Innovative Theatre Awards]] (Off-Off-Broadway), and Diep Tran ''[[American Theatre (magazine)|American Theatre Magazine]]'' (Regional theatre).
==External links== *[http://www.halleonardbooks.com/search/search.do?menuid=10249&subsiteid=166 Official Website]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Theatre World}} [[Category:Publications established in 1945]] [[Category:Non-fiction books about theatre]] [[Category:American non-fiction books]] [[Category:Series of non-fiction books]] [[Category:Broadway theatre]] [[Category:Off-Broadway]] [[Category:Off-Off-Broadway]] [[Category:Regional theatre in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use British English|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox opera | name = Tornrak | composer = [[John Metcalf (composer)|John Metcalf]] | image = | caption = | librettist = [[Michael Wilcox]] | language = English with [[Inuktitut]] sections | based_on = ''Hidalla'' by [[Frank Wedekind]] | premiere_date = {{Start date|1990|02|23|df=y}} | premiere_location = [[Banff Centre]] }} '''''Tornrak''''' is the third [[opera]] by [[Wales|Welsh]] composer [[John Metcalf (composer)|John Metcalf]]. It has an English-language [[libretto]] by [[Michael Wilcox]] with [[Inuktitut]] sections translated by Blendina Makkik. Set between the worlds of the Canadian [[Arctic]] and Victorian Britain, it features [[Inuit throat singing]] and other [[Vocal extended technique|extended vocal techniques]] that give the Arctic scenes a distinct character. The opera was composed between 1986 and 1990 when Metcalf was working in Canada. It was first staged in 1990 in a co-production by the [[Banff Centre]], where Metcalf worked, and the [[Welsh National Opera]] who had commissioned the work. ==Composition== Although [[Welsh National Opera]] (WNO) had first discussed with Metcalf the possibility of his writing a second opera, after ''The Journey'', for them in 1981,Mark Morris "The Genesis of Tornrak" in Simon Rees (ed.) ''Tornrak'' programme, Welsh National Opera, 1990, pp.19–25.Composer profile, p.38 of WNO programme. it was not until 1986 that [[Brian McMaster]], the company's then managing director, first brought the composer and librettist together. After Wilcox had initially started work on another idea, Metcalf contacted him about the true story of a 19th-century [[Inuit]] girl, Milak, who rescued a British sailor, Arthur. Like the character in the opera, the true Milak was shown as a [[circus freak]]; unlike her, she returned home.Michael Wilcox "Writing the libretto" in Simon Rees (ed.) ''Tornrak'' programme, Welsh National Opera 1990, pp.17–18. The development of ''Tornrak'' was greatly influenced by Metcalf's move to Canada later in 1986 to teach on the Music Theatre course at the [[Banff Centre]] in [[Alberta]]. He subsequently became Artistic Director of the programme and Composer-in-Residence.[http://www.banffcentre.ca/theatre/history/opera/production_1996B/biographies.asp#metcalf Biography of Metcalf for ''Kafka's Chimp''], Banff Centre website, Accessed 2 November 2009. Wilcox visited Metcalf in Canada that winter to work on the first draft of the libretto and used the library facilities there to learn about Inuit traditions and mythology. Metcalf too found that the setting enabled him to portray their subject in a more genuine manner. "If I wasn't in the North itself, at least I could now be in contact with a way of looking at the world, the culture, the music, and the language of the Inuit that would have been absolutely impossible in Wales."Quote from Morris "The Genesis of ''Tornrak''" p.19. From 1988 onwards, Metcalf tried out sections of the developing opera in workshops at Banff. Such support for new compositions were an important facet of the programme there. He also had ready access to experienced colleagues such as Keith Turnbull, the Assistant Director on the course, and Richard E. Armstrong who had worked with [[Roy Hart]]. Just as [[Peter Maxwell Davies]] had composed ''[[Eight Songs for a Mad King]]'' with Hart's unusual voice and extended vocal techniques in mind, so Metcalf was able to compose ''Tornrak'' knowing that Armstrong would participate in the opera and also coach the other performers. Armstrong's repertoire of unusual sounds were used in the writing for the spirits and animals. The Inuit parts also required techniques new to Western singers. Fides Krucker, who played the part of Milak in Banff, visited [[Iqaluit]] in 1989 and 1990. There she learnt the [[Inuit throat singing]] techniques which she used in her performances and on which she advised Metcalf. Wilcox encouraged Metcalf to make any changes to the libretto that he needed. He himself revisited Banff again to update the text. Even when he was in Britain, he would respond to urgent phone calls to make changes during the workshops. One of the most significant of the changes to the libretto was the decision to translate much of the first act from English into Inuktitut. Differences in stress patterns between the two languages meant that Metcalf recomposed vocal lines, moving material initially intended to be sung into the orchestral parts. Meanwhile, WNO had agreed to a change in the scale of ''Tornrak''. Instead of it being a [[chamber opera]] using just ten singers to be performed in small venues in Wales, it would now use a larger cast including a chorus and be staged in the large venues normally used by the full company. While those who were involved in the project were sure that the final work was stronger than it would have otherwise been, the many changes resulted in severe delays to the opera's completion and led to repeated postponements of the first performance. ==Roles== {| class="wikitable" !Role !Voice type !Cast in Banff World Preview
23 February 1990

19 May 1990
